stem: A client with deep-vein thrombosis and malnutrition has been on specialized TPN (high-lipid) for 4 weeks. Based on the documentation in the Liver Function & TPN Surveillance Log, what is the best interpretation of the current labs?

options.text: The client is in TPN-induced end-stage hepatic failure with encephalopathy
The high ammonia is a normal byproduct of high-protein TPN
The jaundice is caused by the breakdown of RBCs (Hemolysis)
The prolonged PT is due to a Vitamin C deficiency

rationale.correct: This client is experiencing **fulminant hepatic failure associated with long-term TPN use (a1)**. The high ammonia (112) and asterixis (flapping tremors) confirm **Hepatic Encephalopathy**. Long-term, non-cycled TPN (24/7 lipid infusion) can lead to severe steatohepatitis (fatty liver inflammation) and cholestasis, eventually causing liver failure. The prolonged PT and low platelets (thrombocytopenia) further support the lack of hepatic synthetic function.
clinicalPearls: Ammonia is a neurotoxin; high levels cross the blood-brain barrier causing confusion/coma.
Asterixis = 'Liver Flap.' It is a hallmark sign of Stage II encephalopathy.
Cylcing TPN (giving the liver hours without fat/glucose) is the best way to prevent this complication.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking the ammonia is just from the TPN amino acids (a2).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: While amino acids are broken down into ammonia, a healthy liver converts them to urea immediately. If the ammonia is 112, the liver is NOT converting it. It is not 'normal.'

mnemonic.title: Flap & Fail
mnemonic.expansion: Asterixis (Flap). Ammonia (Brain fog). ALT (Liver kill). TPN (The cause).

exhibits.title: Nursing Physical
exhibits.content: Current: Client is difficult to arouse (Stage II Encephalopathy). Flapping tremors (Asterixis) noted when hands are extended. Sclera are deeply jaundiced. No prior history of alcohol use or hepatitis.

exhibits.title: Medication History
exhibits.content: Note: TPN includes a 20% lipid emulsion given 24 hours/day. Client has received no oral intake for 30 days.
